Word Closure-Based Metamorphic Testing for Machine Translation

Xiaoyuan Xie xxie@whu.edu.cn ,  Shuo Jin imjinshuo@whu.edu.cn School of Computer Science, Wuhan UniversityChina ,  Songqiang Chen i9s.chen@connect.ust.hk  and  Shing-Chi Cheung scc@cse.ust.hk Department of Computer Science and Engineering, The Hong Kong University of Science and TechnologyChina
(2024)
Abstract.

With the wide application of machine translation, the testing of Machine Translation Systems (MTSs) has attracted much attention. Recent works apply Metamorphic Testing (MT) to address the oracle problem in MTS testing. Existing MT methods for MTS generally follow the workflow of input transformation and output relation comparison, which generates a follow-up input sentence by mutating the source input and compares the source and follow-up output translations to detect translation errors, respectively. These methods use various input transformations to generate the test case pairs and have successfully triggered numerous translation errors. However, they have limitations in performing fine-grained and rigorous output relation comparison and thus may report many false alarms and miss many true errors. In this paper, we propose a word closure-based output comparison method to address the limitations of the existing MTS MT methods. We first propose word closure as a new comparison unit, where each closure includes a group of correlated input and output words in the test case pair. Word closures suggest the linkages between the appropriate fragment in the source output translation and its counterpart in the follow-up output for comparison. Next, we compare the semantics on the level of word closure to identify the translation errors. In this way, we perform a fine-grained and rigorous semantic comparison for the outputs and thus realize more effective violation identification. We evaluate our method with the test cases generated by five existing input transformations and the translation outputs from three popular MTSs. Results show that our method significantly outperforms the existing works in violation identification by improving the precision and recall and achieving an average increase of 29.9% in F1 score. It also helps to increase the F1 score of translation error localization by 35.9%.

1. Introduction

Machine translation systems (MTSs) have seen more and more applications in our daily life. Many popular MTSs, such as Google Translate and Bing Microsoft Translator, are providing translation services for millions of users every day (Shankland, 2013; Clayton, 2013). However, the automatically generated translations are not always correct. If not recognized, the incorrect translations provided by MTS can lead to significant issues, such as political conflicts (Macdonald, 2015), false arrest (Post, 2012; Davies, 2017), financial loss (Vidhayasai et al., 2015; Okrent, 2016), and vaccine mishap (Bell, 2021). In order to avoid these problems, there have been a few testing methods proposed for MTS to detect its potential mistranslations.

One promising idea to efficiently test MTS is to apply Metamorphic Testing (MT) (Chen et al., 1998). Some early methods adopt the round-trip translation to construct follow-up cases (Somers, 2005; Koehn and Monz, 2006; Shigenobu, 2007; Cao et al., 2022). Recently, a few new methods propose more sophisticated Metamorphic Relations (MRs) that manipulate particular components of an input sentence to generate follow-up cases (He et al., 2020, 2021; Gupta et al., 2020; Sun et al., 2022; Ji et al., 2021). In the output comparison, these new methods check whether there are cases where the same (or different) input word is translated into different (or similar) meanings. If yes, there is a violation being reported, indicating at least one translation error. These new methods include SIT (He et al., 2020), CAT (Sun et al., 2022), Purity (He et al., 2021), CIT (Ji et al., 2021) and PatInv (Gupta et al., 2020). Test cases generated by the input transformations in these five methods successfully trigger numerous mistranslations of MTS.

However, these methods still have several limitations regarding “what to compare” and “how to compare”. In terms of “what to compare”, we identified three major limitations: (1) Some methods cannot compare two output translations at a fine granularity for precise comparison. Specifically, SIT and CAT detect the violation according to the similarity between the entire (estimated) unchanged part of the two translations. However, such an overall similarity can not effectively reflect the fine-grained differences between the translations. As a result, violations can be incorrectly revealed on some correct translations while some translation errors can be missed. For instance, our experiments conducted on the English-to-Chinese translation service of Google Translate show that 48.0% and 40.6% of false alarms and 41.2% and 100.0% of missing detections in SIT and CAT can be attributed to this limitation. (2) Some methods lack the linkage between the fragment in the source output and its counterpart in the follow-up output to implement rigorous comparison. Specifically, without such linkages, Purity and CIT have to adopt relatively loose comparison strategies to judge the correctness of outputs, which may miss many translation errors. For example, we have found that 42.9% and 31.7% of missing detections in English-to-Chinese translations from Google Translate can be due to this limitation for Purity and CIT, respectively. (3) Some method (i.e., PatInv) ignores to detect the incorrect translations of the unchanged input words, which may also miss many translation errors. Take the testing of the English-to-Chinese translation from Google Translate as an example, all the violations missed by PatInv can be attributed to this limitation according to our experiment. In terms of “how to compare”, we summarized two limitations: (1) Some methods that apply structure-based comparison methods fail to detect the incorrect translation that has the same structure but incorrect semantic meanings as its counterpart. Based on our experiment, when testing Google Translate to translate English into Chinese, this limitation causes 52.9% and 68.3% of missing detections for SIT and CIT, respectively. (2) Some methods adopt text-based comparison methods and thus cannot recognize the synonyms between the two translations. For example, in our experiment on the English-to-Chinese translations of Google Translate, we found that 72.5% and 88.2% of false alarms for CAT and Purity, respectively, can be attributed to this limitation. Thus, these limitations are pervasive and largely hinder the effectiveness of current methods.

Meanwhile, it is challenging to address the aforementioned limitations and achieve rigorous output violation checking. Specifically, it is necessary to link the fine-grained counterparts in the source and follow-up translations, which will be the proper comparison subjects against the metamorphic relation. To achieve a fine-grained violation identification, the native grammar unit, such as clause, phrase or word, is not suitable to work as the counterparts since they are not flexible and hard to match. Besides, to achieve a rigorous comparison, building linkages between these counterparts is challenging due to the poor performance of word-level alignment tools.

In this work, we propose to perform MT for MTS based on a new concept called word closure to alleviate the limitations in the existing output comparison methods. We first rule out the coarse comparison on the overall similarity of the outputs. The core idea of our solution is to link each appropriate fragment in the source output and its counterpart in the follow-up output (i.e. to construct word closures), such that a finer-grained and rigorous comparison can be realized. In this way, we can properly address the limitations of “what to compare”. Regarding the limitations of “how to compare”, we compare the translations by evaluating their semantics to address the limitations of the structure- and text-based methods. With the help of word closure and semantic comparison, we can detect many missed errors (i.e. false negatives) and incorrectly detected errors (i.e. false positives) in existing works. In addition, the merit of “fine granularity” enables our method to locate the fine-grained violations more precisely, i.e., the specific words that cause the overall violation within the test case pair.

We perform a comprehensive evaluation of our proposed output comparison approach to detect translation errors from three popular MTSs. The experiment results show that our approach can effectively reduce the false negatives and false positives in the existing methods, and lead to a significant improvement in the overall performance. Specifically, the average increase in F1 score is as high as 29.9% as compared with the five existing methods. For fine-grained violation locating, our approach outperforms the existing methods with an average increase in F1 score of 35.9%, which demonstrates the advantage of our method in locating the specific words that cause the overall violation within the test case pair.

To summarize, this paper addresses the limitations of violation identification methods applied by the existing MT testing works for MTS to achieve better performance in translation error detection. Our contributions are outlined below:

  • •

    We review the latest MTS metamorphic testing works whose MRs mutate the source input sentence, summarize the primary limitations in their output relation comparison methods, and show the impact of such limitations on the error detection performance.

  • •

    We propose a word closure-based output comparison method to alleviate the limitations of existing works in violation identification. Our approach can link each appropriate fragment in the source output and its counterpart in the follow-up output (i.e. to construct word closures), such that a finer-grained and rigorous comparison can be realized. Combined with semantic comparison, our method can properly resolve the problems of “what to compare” and “how to compare”.

  • •

    The built linkages between the fragments in the source translation and their counterparts in the follow-up translation via word closure can further support the fine-grained violation localization, which can pinpoint the specific words giving rise to the detected violations.

  • •

    The experiment results show that our word closure-based comparison method is very effective in reducing the false positives and false negatives in existing methods in both the widely-studied English-Chinese translation and the unexplored essential Chinese-English translation scenarios, and hence leads to a significant improvement in the overall violation detection ability. Specifically, our method achieves an average increase of 29.9% in the F1 score as compared with existing methods. In terms of locating fine-grained violations, our approach achieves an average increase of 35.9% in F1 score than the existing methods.

The dataset, replication package, and supplementary materials for this paper are available online at (DAT, 2023).

The remaining paper is organized as follows. In Section 2, we review the five target latest MT methods for MTS testing. Section 3 summarizes the limitations of existing work and illustrates specific examples, which motivate our work. In Section 4, we introduce our word closure-based output comparison approach and explain its detailed implementations. Section 5 lists the experimental setup and Section 6 presents the experiment results and analysis for the research questions. In Section 7, we study the helpfulness of our approach in enhancing the robustness of the machine translation model, summarize the limitations of our approach and outline some potential directions for future advancements. Section 8 discusses the threats to validity of this work, and Section 9 overviews the related works. Finally, we conclude the paper in Section 10.

2. Background

Recent automated MTS testing methods (Somers, 2005; Koehn and Monz, 2006; Shigenobu, 2007; Cao et al., 2022; Zhou and Sun, 2018; He et al., 2020, 2021; Gupta et al., 2020; Sun et al., 2020, 2022; Ji et al., 2021) are mostly based on Metamorphic Testing (MT). MT solves the oracle problem of MTS testing via Metamorphic Relations (MRs), which describe the necessary properties of MTS in relation to multiple inputs and their expected outputs (Chen et al., 2018). The violation of the MRs indicates the incorrect translation of MTS. Some early proposed methods test MTS via round-trip translation (Somers, 2005; Koehn and Monz, 2006; Shigenobu, 2007; Cao et al., 2022). Recently, some new methods focus on MRs that manipulate particular components of an input sentence (Zhou and Sun, 2018; He et al., 2020, 2021; Gupta et al., 2020; Sun et al., 2020, 2022; Ji et al., 2021). Specifically, these MRs consist of two primary steps to test MTS, i.e., the input transformation (denoted as IT) and the output relation comparison (denoted as OR). Given a source input sentence (denoted as Sssubscript𝑆𝑠S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT), the testing method transforms Sssubscript𝑆𝑠S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT into a new follow-up input sentence (denoted as Sfsubscript𝑆𝑓S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) according to the input transformation of the MR. Next, the translations of both Sssubscript𝑆𝑠S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Sfsubscript𝑆𝑓S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, denoted as Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, respectively, are derived by running MTS with Sssubscript𝑆𝑠S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Sfsubscript𝑆𝑓S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Finally, Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are compared to check if Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT violate the expected output relation defined by the MR. If a violation is identified, there should be translation errors within Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In this paper, we propose an approach to effectively enhance the MTS testing methods that transform the input sentence, which are more popular recently.

In the family of MT-based MTS testing methods that transforms the input sentence, five recent methods, i.e., SIT (He et al., 2020), PatInv (Gupta et al., 2020), Purity (He et al., 2021), CIT (Ji et al., 2021), and CAT (Sun et al., 2022), have demonstrated outstanding performance in detecting incorrect translations of MTS. In the following, we introduce the MRs of these methods:

  1. (1)

    SIT: SIT is based on the MR that the translations of similar sentences should exhibit similar sentence structure. It replaces one word in Sssubscript𝑆𝑠S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with another word that keeps the same part of speech to generate a similar follow-up sentence Sfsubscript𝑆𝑓S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We denoted this input transformation as IT-1. Next, SIT compares whether the constituency parse tree or dependency parse tree of two output translations Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are similar. This output relation is denoted as OR-1. If the distance between the two parse trees exceeds the predefined threshold, it reports this pair of test cases as a violation.

  2. (2)

    CAT: CAT employs the MR that the translations of two sentences with one different word should be similar except for those of the different words. CAT replaces one word in Sssubscript𝑆𝑠S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with another word similar in semantics to generate the Sfsubscript𝑆𝑓S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (IT-2). To check whether the two input sentences are translated similarly except for the replaced words (OR-2), CAT leverages a strategy to roughly remove the translations of the replaced words from comparison and calculates the similarity score between the estimated unchanged part of the two translations. If the overall similarity score is below the predefined threshold, CAT reports a violation as the translations of the same input words are largely different.

  3. (3)

    Purity: Purity is based on the MR that a noun phrase should be translated similarly in different contexts. Purity proposes the input transformation to extract a noun phrase from Sssubscript𝑆𝑠S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as the follow-up input Sfsubscript𝑆𝑓S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (IT-3). To check whether the extracted noun phrase is translated similarly in Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (OR-3), Purity measures how many word occurrences are in Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT but not in Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as the distance between the source and follow-up translations of the identical noun phrase. If the distance is above the threshold, Purity considers that the target noun phrase is translated differently in Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and reports this test case pair as a violation.

  4. (4)

    CIT: The MR of CIT is that the constituency structure of a sentence’s translation should remain unchanged if an adjunct, optional constituent of a sentence, is inserted in the sentence. The input transformation proposed by CIT is to add an adjunct into Sssubscript𝑆𝑠S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to generate the Sfsubscript𝑆𝑓S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (IT-4). Given an original sentence, CIT leverages the sentence compression tool, which can automatically compress a sentence by removing all the adjuncts from it, to identify the adjuncts in the sentence. With the compressed sentence as Sssubscript𝑆𝑠S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, CIT adds one identified adjunct to generate the Sfsubscript𝑆𝑓S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. To verify whether the constituency structure of Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT remains unchanged in Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (OR-4), CIT checks whether all the paths in the constituency parse tree of Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT exist in that of Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. CIT will report a violation if any path violates the above expected output relation.

  5. (5)

    PatInv: PatInv generates sentences with different meanings to detect translation errors. The MR of PatInv is that sentences with different meanings should have different translations. PatInv proposes two implementations to change the meaning of the source input sentence Sssubscript𝑆𝑠S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to generate the Sfsubscript𝑆𝑓S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (IT-5). The first method is to replace one word in Sssubscript𝑆𝑠S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with a word of different semantics. Another one is to remove a meaningful word or phrase from Sssubscript𝑆𝑠S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. As Sssubscript𝑆𝑠S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Sfsubscript𝑆𝑓S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT have different meanings, their translations Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are supposed to be different (OR-5). If Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are the same, PatInv will report a violation.

As shown in Table 1, the five testing methods for MTS can be divided into categories according to their output comparison strategies and input transformations. Based on the output comparison strategy, the five testing methods are divided into two general categories, i.e., “Equivalence comparison” (Class-A and Class-B) including SIT, CAT, Purity, and CIT, and ‘Unequivalence comparison” (Class-C) including PatInv. Within “Equivalence comparison”, the four methods can be further divided into two sub-categories according to their input transformations. SIT and CAT are included in “Word replacement” (Class-A). They both replace one word in the source input sentence to generate a similar follow-up input sentence. Although Purity and CIT apply two seemingly different input transformations, i.e., decremental and incremental transformations, they both build a pair of input sentences with different lengths, wherein the shorter sentence is a part of the longer one. Thus, we categorize them together as Class-B. For clarity, we summarize the output relation comparison method of these three categories in the last column of Table 1.

Besides, the five testing methods can also be categorized based on their strategies in evaluating the similarity (or dissimilarity) between the output translations. Specifically, SIT and CIT use “structure-based comparison” and CAT, Purity, and PatInv use “text-based comparison”.

However, all these categories of MTS testing methods have limitations in their output comparison methods. Such limitations will be discussed in Section 3.

3. Motivation

The five metamorphic testing methods for MTS have successfully detected mistranslations of MTS with their input transformations and output relations. However, the identified mistranslations based on MR violation can be wrong due to the limitations of their output relation comparison methods. The wrong identification results can be categorized into False Negatives (FNs) and False Positives (FPs). An FP means a pair of test cases, whose outputs satisfy the expected output relation of MR, is misidentified as a violation. Conversely, if a true violation is missed, an FN will be counted. In the following, we illustrate each limitation with practical examples 111For more detailed explanations of the examples (e.g., Chinese meanings), please refer to our online artifact (DAT, 2023)..

  1. (1)

    Comparison methods of Class-A cannot compare two output translations at a fine granularity for precise comparison. SIT and CAT compare the overall sentence similarity between the entire (estimated) unchanged part of Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to detect the violation. Specifically, SIT checks whether the two sentences are translated similarly by computing the distance between the entire Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the entire Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Meanwhile, although CAT approximately removes the translations of the mutated words from the comparison, it computes the overall similarity score between the estimated unchanged part of translations in Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to detect the violation. If the overall distance or similarity cannot satisfy the preset threshold, they regard this pair of test cases as a violation. However, such a coarse comparison strategy will inevitably introduce some FPs or FNs. On one hand, they can miss some finer violations, which do not lead to an obvious decrease in the overall similarity between Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This will lead to FNs. An FN example of SIT is shown in Fig. 1. SIT generates Sfsubscript𝑆𝑓S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by replacing the word “treasure” in Sssubscript𝑆𝑠S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with “interior”, as marked in bold. In the translations Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, there is a redundant translation “美国” (the U.S.) in Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and the same input words “taking down listing” in Sssubscript𝑆𝑠S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Sfsubscript𝑆𝑓S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are translated as different meanings in Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, i.e., “下架” (removed from shelves) and “删除清单” (delete list). Therefore, this example is indeed a violation. However, due to the small difference introduced by the above translation error, the overall distance score between the parse trees of Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is lower than the threshold defined by SIT. As a result, the output translations for this test case pair are identified as non-violation by SIT. Similar FN cases can be found in CAT as well. On the other hand, coarse-grained comparison may misidentify the test cases that satisfy the output relation as a violation, which leads to FPs. An FP example of CAT is shown in Fig. 1. CAT generates Sfsubscript𝑆𝑓S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by replacing the word “Monday” in Sssubscript𝑆𝑠S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with “Sunday”, as marked in bold. Although the translation of the adverbial clause “when everything is ready” is placed at different positions in Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, as highlighted in blue, there is no violation within Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as they share similar meanings (Svenonius, 2002). However, CAT misidentifies it as a violation due to the overall low similarity between Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caused by the different positions of the adverbial clause. Similar FPs can also be found in SIT.

  2. (2)

    Comparison methods of Class-B lack the linkage between the fragment in the source output and its counterpart in the follow-up output to implement rigorous comparison. Given a sentence to translate, Purity and CIT generate a new input sentence by adding or deleting contents. Unlike Class-A methods that use the overall similarity to detect the translation errors for two relatively similar input sentences, Purity and CIT judge the inclusion relationship between the outputs for a pair of inputs. Specifically, they check whether the words or syntax parse tree paths of the shorter translation exist in that of the longer one token by token. However, this inclusion relationship checking method is relatively loose. It can lead to FNs in some cases when the shorter translation misses some necessary content or the longer translation contains redundant content. An FN example of CIT is shown in Fig. 1. CIT generates Sfsubscript𝑆𝑓S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by inserting the adjunct “Therefore,” into Sssubscript𝑆𝑠S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, as marked in bold. Because the same input word “assorted” is translated as “什锦” in Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT but missed in Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, there is a violation over this test case pair. However, CIT identifies this test case pair as non-violation because the constituency parse tree of Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT includes every path in the constituency parse tree of Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. As a result, lacking the linkages between the counterparts between Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, CIT implements a relatively loose comparison strategy and fails to detect the violation in this example. Similar FNs can be found in Purity as well.

  3. (3)

    Comparison method of Class-C ignores to detect the incorrect translations of the unchanged input words. PatInv only compares whether the altered words in Sssubscript𝑆𝑠S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Sfsubscript𝑆𝑓S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are translated differently while ignoring the correctness of the other translations. As a result, PatInv fails to detect the incorrect translations in Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of the same input words, which leads to FNs. An FN example of PatInv is shown in Fig. 1. PatInv generates Sfsubscript𝑆𝑓S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by replacing the word “pandemic” in Sssubscript𝑆𝑠S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with “holiday”, as marked in bold. Although the same input word “policies” is translated as different meanings in Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, i.e., “保单” (guarantee slip) and “政策” (policies), according to its output checking rule, PatInv regards this example as non-violation just because Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are different.

As a reminder, apart from the limitations from the above “what to compare” aspect, current solutions to “how to compare” also have problems.

First, the structured-based comparison methods fail to detect the incorrect translation that has the same structure as its counterpart. Incorrect translation within Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT do not always lead to the different structures between Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Therefore, structured-based comparison methods can miss many incorrect translations, leading to FNs.

Secondly, the text-based comparison methods cannot recognize the synonyms between the two translations. Text-based comparison methods, which adopt string-based metrics (e.g. BLEU), measure the similarity between two translations based on the plain lexicographic match without considering meaning (Colombo et al., 2022). As a result, CAT and Purity can misidentify the synonyms within Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as violations, leading to FPs. For PatInv, which reports a violation only if the two translations are the same, the test case pairs with violations may be ignored due to the differences involved by synonyms, leading to FNs. To illustrate the limitation of the text-based comparison methods, we present an FP example of Purity in Fig. 1. Purity extracts a noun phrase from Sssubscript𝑆𝑠S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as the Sfsubscript𝑆𝑓S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Although there are many synonyms between Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, e.g., “考试” (tests) in Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and “测试” (tests) in Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, there is no violation between Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT because these synonyms share similar semantic meanings. Unable to recognize these synonyms, Purity misidentifies this example as a violation because four words from Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can not be found in Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the sum of which is above the threshold.

To summarize, every existing output comparison method has at least two of the above limitations, from the aspects of both “what to compare” and “how to compare”. These limitations, as summarized in Table 2, may lead to FPs, FNs, or both and therefore degrade the testing method performance. On one hand, reporting many FPs reduces the reliability of the test results and requires additional manual filtering to identify true translation errors. On the other hand, some serious translation errors within the FNs may be undetected and unfixed, posing potential risks to the practical application of MTS. Furthermore, too many FNs may even mislead users into believing that the quality of MTS is dependable and using MTS without hesitation in some key areas. In order to achieve more adequate violation identification, in this work, we propose a word-closure-based output comparison method to address the aforementioned limitations.

4. Methodology

4.1. Core Idea and Approach Overview

In this work, we propose a new output relation comparison approach for Metamorphic Testing of Machine Translation. It addresses the limitations regarding “what to compare” and “how to compare” of the output checking method in existing methods introduced in Section 3. It realizes more rigorous output checking and can be used with existing input transformation methods.

First, to address the limitations from “what to compare”, we propose a new type of granularity, namely “word closure”. We perform output comparisons on this granularity level. As mentioned in Section 3, it is too coarse to compare the source and follow-up outputs by measuring the overall similarity between translations. A finer-grained entity is needed for comparison. Meanwhile, simply adopting native grammar units such as words, phrases, or clauses cannot meet the requirement in our MT scenario. The main reason is that, in MT, test cases are changed via various transformations. As a result, we usually need to compare a particular fragment in the source output and its counterpart in the follow-up output against some relations (i.e. MRs). In other words, the core challenge during this process is to identify the corresponding relation between a particular fragment in the source output and its counterpart in the follow-up output. Comparisons against MRs should be performed by referring to these relations. Simply adopting the native grammar units cannot achieve this goal, as these units across the source and follow-up outputs do not always show explicit corresponding relations. In this work, we propose “word closure” to address the above challenge. A word closure comprises the appropriate counterparts in a pair of source and follow-up outputs, which are linked for comparison against the output relation, as well as their corresponding fragments in the source and follow-up inputs. Section 4.2 will explain the details of word closure.

To construct the word closures, word mappings between the input sentences and output translations are necessary. It is not difficult to think of adopting a general word alignment tool, which is also mentioned in (He et al., 2021; Sun et al., 2020). However, the accuracy of basic word alignments does not meet our requirements. Thus, we propose two algorithms to refine the word alignment results, which are described in Section 4.3. After the construction of all word closures for a pair of metamorphic test cases, comparisons against the MR will be performed between the translation fragments linked by word closures.

The idea of performing comparison within the linked counterparts in the source and follow-up outputs based on word closures allows us to address the limitations of Class-A, Class-B, and Class-C. Firstly, we use word closure to split the translations into finer granularity, which is shorter than the comparison unit of entire translations adopted by Class-A. This helps to avoid the FPs and FNs introduced by a coarse comparison granularity. Secondly, word closures can link each fragment from Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with its counterpart in Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This enables a more rigorous comparison by clearly identifying the elements to compare, which cannot be realized by Class-B. In addition, Class-C only compares the translations of changed words. Meanwhile, word closures can be utilized to compare the translations of both the same input words and the changed input words to detect the incorrect translations more adequately.

By considering the limitations from “how to compare”, we propose to compare the semantic similarity (or dissimilarity if needed) of the translations to detect violations. On one hand, comparing the semantic similarity can expose the violations with different meanings but identical structures, which are ignored by the structure-based comparison methods. On the other hand, semantic-based comparison can identify the synonyms within the source and follow-up translations due to their similar semantics, thereby avoiding the FPs and FNs caused by the text-based comparison methods. When comparing translations of the same input words, we detect violations based on their semantic similarity. For the translations of the changed input words, we check their semantic dissimilarity (similarity) if the changed input words have different (similar) meanings. As a reminder, in our approach, we compare the semantic similarity at a fine granularity, i.e., word closure. By properly addressing the limitations about “what to compare”, the semantic comparison can be performed more accurately.

Table 3 briefly summarizes how our method addresses each limitation of the existing output comparison methods for MTS testing.

Fig. 2 presents an overview of our approach. The input comprises a pair of source and follow-up input sentences Sssubscript𝑆𝑠S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Sfsubscript𝑆𝑓S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT generated through the input transformation of MRs, as well as their translations Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (i.e., source and follow-up outputs) returned by MTS. To detect whether MTS violates the MR on the test case pair, our approach involves two modules for constructing word closures from the test case pair and one module for detecting the violation by evaluating the semantics of the translation counterparts linked by word closures. The construction of word closure requires the word mappings between input sentences and output translations. Thus, in the first module “Refined Word Alignment”, we adopt the word alignment tool and propose two refinement algorithms to build the word alignment between Sssubscript𝑆𝑠S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (Sfsubscript𝑆𝑓S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) and Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT). Next, in the second module “Word Closure Construction”, we construct all the word closures from the input test cases to match the finer granularity between the two translations. Finally, in the last module “Translation Comparison”, we compare the semantics of the translation fragments matched by the constructed word closures to detect the violations. The detected violations are returned as the output. In the following, we will illustrate the definition of word closure, the implementation of the three modules, and the finalized metamorphic relation of our approach.

4.2. Word Closure

Before we formally define word closure, we want to show the problems of using native grammar units for comparison. Fig. 3 uses the example of PatInv-FN shown in Fig. 1, where the follow-up input sentence Sfsubscript𝑆𝑓S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is generated by replacing the word “pandemic” in Sssubscript𝑆𝑠S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as “holiday”. In contrast to PatInv which only requires two outputs to be different, a more reasonable comparison should check whether the same input words are translated similarly and the different input words are translated dissimilarly in Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. However, to achieve this goal, the first necessary step is to link the counterparts in the source and follow-up outputs. Now, let us consider the naive method that adopts native grammar units of clauses, phrases, and words represented by the boxes in Fig. 3. We identify two problems that motivate us to design a proper granularity for comparison.

The constituency parse tree represents the clause and phrase structures in a sentence. According to the constituency parse tree of Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we extract the clauses and phrases of Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT respectively in Fig. 3. At the clause level, we can identify one clause in Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and one clause in Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, both marked as “IP” (simple clause). At the phrase level, we can identify five phrases in Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and four phrases in Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, marked as “NP” (noun phrase), “DNP” (phrase ended with “的”), “PP” (preposition phrase), and “VP”(verb phrase). At the word level, a tokenizer is adopted to split Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT into tokens. The first problem is that the grammar units in Tssubscript𝑇𝑠\boldsymbol{T_{s}}bold_italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT do not have explicit linkage with their counterparts in Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓\boldsymbol{T_{f}}bold_italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This lack of linkage creates confusion when determining which units in Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT respectively should be compared against the MR, particularly for grammar units such as phrases and words that have multiple options. Simply comparing these grammar units between Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT one by one to detect their difference as the violation is unreasonable as Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are not supposed to be totally identical due to different input sentences. Another problem is that establishing the links between these grammar units is unpracticable in some cases. At the clause level, the two clauses in Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are not the translation of the same input words and therefore should not be linked for comparison. At the phrase level, we can only establish a linkage between the noun phrases (highlighted in blue), i.e., “大多数 保单” in Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and “大多数 政策” in Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. For other phrases, their corresponding input words overlap only partially, such as “1 月份” (January) in Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and “在 一月份” (In January) in Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, therefore should not be matched. At the word level, even though more units can match their counterparts in another translation (highlighted in blue), there are still many words that can not be linked as they correspond to different input words.

To address these problems, we propose the concept of “word closure”. Word closures provide a more appropriate granularity of comparison, meanwhile can intrinsically support establishing the necessary linkage between the fragment in Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and its counterpart in Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for output relation checking. Word closure construction will be performed on the sets of words in Sssubscript𝑆𝑠S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Sfsubscript𝑆𝑓S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, respectively. As a reminder, identical words in the sets of source and follow-up cases should be treated as different objects in our method.

Definition 0 (Word Closure).

wssuperscript𝑤𝑠w^{s}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, wfsuperscript𝑤𝑓w^{f}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, tssuperscript𝑡𝑠t^{s}italic_t Sssubscript𝑆𝑠S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, follow-up input Sfsubscript𝑆𝑓S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, source translation Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and follow-up translation Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, respectively. Words wssuperscript𝑤𝑠w^{s}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, wfsuperscript𝑤𝑓w^{f}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, tssuperscript𝑡𝑠t^{s}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and tfsuperscript𝑡𝑓t^{f}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT can be aggregated in the same word closure, iff these words have some correlation with one another, but are not correlated with words outside this closure. As a reminder, it is possible that one or more sets in this aggregation (but not all) are empty, and some words in Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are not included in any closure (the detailed construction process will be introduced in Section 4.4).

By definition, a word closure is a minimal aggregation of linked words, and there is no overlapping among different closures. For example, the last row of Fig. 3 presents the word closures constructed from PatInv-FN. The dotted arrows in the word closures represent the correlations between the words within the input sentences and output translations. In the first word closure, the four words, i.e., “In” from Sssubscript𝑆𝑠S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, “In” from Sfsubscript𝑆𝑓S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, “在” from Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and “在” from Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT have correlations with each other and no correlation with the words outside this closure. The other four closures also meet these properties, and there is no overlapping among different word closures. The solid arrows linking Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT signify the linkages constructed by word closures. It can be observed that word closure establishes the linkage between the fragment in Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and its counterpart in Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, covering the majority of tokens in both translations. Therefore, compared with the native grammar granularities, word closure is more appropriate in identifying violations as the linkages built by word closure enable us to perform a fine-grained output comparison against the output relation.

In the next three sections, we will introduce how to construct word closures for a pair of metamorphic test cases and their outputs, as well as how to compare the outputs against the expected relations. Specifically, we need a refined word alignment to build the correlations between the input and output words, based on which we build closures.

4.3. Refined Word Alignment

The construction of word closure depends on the word alignment between the input sentences and output translations. However, the accuracy of current word alignment tools cannot meet our requirements (He et al., 2021; Sun et al., 2020): we found that current tools may overlook certain word alignments, resulting in many ineffective word closures that fail to indicate the correct linkage between the source and follow-up output counterparts. Thus, we first employ a word alignment tool to initially align the words in the input texts and output translations of the source and follow-up test cases respectively. Then, we match the words in the source and follow-up inputs, and next use two heuristic strategies to refine these missed alignments for better construction of word closures. Specifically, we first adopt a state-of-the-art word alignment tool, AWESOME, (Dou and Neubig, 2021) to build the basic word alignments between Sssubscript𝑆𝑠S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (Sfsubscript𝑆𝑓S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) and Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) and store them in a dictionary Mssubscript𝑀𝑠M_{s}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (Mfsubscript𝑀𝑓M_{f}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT). For each word w𝑤witalic_w in Sssubscript𝑆𝑠S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT), AWESOME stores in Ms⁢[w]subscript𝑀𝑠delimited-[]𝑤M_{s}[w]italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_w ] a set of words {w1,w2,…}subscript𝑤1subscript𝑤2…\{w_{1},w_{2},\ldots\}{ italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … } in Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (Sssubscript𝑆𝑠S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) that are aligned with w𝑤witalic_w. Mfsubscript𝑀𝑓M_{f}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT functions similarly for Sfsubscript𝑆𝑓S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We then align the unmutated input words in Sssubscript𝑆𝑠S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Sfsubscript𝑆𝑓S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and store the mapping in the dictionary Misubscript𝑀𝑖M_{i}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT according to the input transformation. The mutated input words between Sssubscript𝑆𝑠S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Sfsubscript𝑆𝑓S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are not considered because they are hard to be precisely aligned. For each unmutated word w𝑤witalic_w in Sssubscript𝑆𝑠S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (Sfsubscript𝑆𝑓S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT), Mi⁢[w]subscript𝑀𝑖delimited-[]𝑤M_{i}[w]italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_w ] returns its corresponding unmutated word {w′}superscript𝑤′\{w^{\prime}\}{ italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } in Sfsubscript𝑆𝑓S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (Sssubscript𝑆𝑠S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT); for each mutate word w′superscript𝑤′w^{\prime}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, Mi⁢[w′]subscript𝑀𝑖delimited-[]superscript𝑤′M_{i}[w^{\prime}]italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] returns an empty set. Next, we apply two strategies to refine the word alignments within Mssubscript𝑀𝑠M_{s}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Mfsubscript𝑀𝑓M_{f}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which are built by the word alignment tool.

Refinement strategy 1: The first strategy helps to recover the missed word alignments according to the constituency parse tree of the translation. If an input word is translated as multiple words in the target language, the multiple output words should be aligned with this input word. However, the word alignment tool may miss some of the alignments between them. Fig. 4 shows the alignments unrecognized by the word alignment tool for the example of PatInv-FN. In the example, the “January” in the input sentence is translated as two Chinese words (”1” and ”月份”), and the input word “pandemic” is also translated as two Chinese words (“大” and “流行”). However, according to the basic word alignments from AWESOME, “January” is only aligned with “1” but without “月份”, and “pandemic” is only aligned with “流行” but without “大”. In most cases, the multiple translated words corresponding to an input word are always in the same phrase in the translation and function as a whole unit (Wikipedia, 2023b). Thus, our refinement strategy 1 is to align the words within the same phrase in the translation to identical input words. This strategy builds the missing alignments mentioned above, where the phrase structures are recognized based on the constituency parse tree of the translation. As a reminder, we do not consider verb phrases because they may contain too many modifiers to represent very complex semantics (Wikipedia, 2023c).

The process of refinement strategy 1 is illustrated in Algorithm 1. Based on the basic word alignments M𝑀Mitalic_M between the input sentence S𝑆Sitalic_S and its translation T𝑇Titalic_T, we first collect the words in T𝑇Titalic_T that are not aligned with any words in S𝑆Sitalic_S and denote them as Tu⁢n⁢a⁢l⁢i⁢g⁢n⁢e⁢dsubscript𝑇𝑢𝑛𝑎𝑙𝑖𝑔𝑛𝑒𝑑T_{unaligned}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u italic_n italic_a italic_l italic_i italic_g italic_n italic_e italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (Lines 1-6). For each word wtsubscript𝑤𝑡w_{t}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in Tu⁢n⁢a⁢l⁢i⁢g⁢n⁢e⁢dsubscript𝑇𝑢𝑛𝑎𝑙𝑖𝑔𝑛𝑒𝑑T_{unaligned}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u italic_n italic_a italic_l italic_i italic_g italic_n italic_e italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we locate the smallest subtree s⁢u⁢b⁢t⁢r⁢e⁢e𝑠𝑢𝑏𝑡𝑟𝑒𝑒subtreeitalic_s italic_u italic_b italic_t italic_r italic_e italic_e that includes both wtsubscript𝑤𝑡w_{t}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and other words in T𝑇Titalic_T, based on the constituency parse tree T⁢r⁢e⁢e𝑇𝑟𝑒𝑒Treeitalic_T italic_r italic_e italic_e of T𝑇Titalic_T (Lines 7-8). If s⁢u⁢b⁢t⁢r⁢e⁢e𝑠𝑢𝑏𝑡𝑟𝑒𝑒subtreeitalic_s italic_u italic_b italic_t italic_r italic_e italic_e is marked as a phrase and not a verb phrase, we identify the leaf nodes l⁢e⁢a⁢v⁢e⁢s𝑙𝑒𝑎𝑣𝑒𝑠leavesitalic_l italic_e italic_a italic_v italic_e italic_s in s⁢u⁢b⁢t⁢r⁢e⁢e𝑠𝑢𝑏𝑡𝑟𝑒𝑒subtreeitalic_s italic_u italic_b italic_t italic_r italic_e italic_e that are adjacent to t𝑡titalic_t (Lines 9-10). Next, we find the input words St⁢a⁢r⁢g⁢e⁢tsubscript𝑆𝑡𝑎𝑟𝑔𝑒𝑡S_{target}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_a italic_r italic_g italic_e italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that are aligned with l⁢e⁢a⁢v⁢e⁢s𝑙𝑒𝑎𝑣𝑒𝑠leavesitalic_l italic_e italic_a italic_v italic_e italic_s, denoted as St⁢a⁢r⁢g⁢e⁢tsubscript𝑆𝑡𝑎𝑟𝑔𝑒𝑡S_{target}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_a italic_r italic_g italic_e italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (Line 11). Finally, we build the missed word alignment between wtsubscript𝑤𝑡w_{t}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and each word wssubscript𝑤𝑠w_{s}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in St⁢a⁢r⁢g⁢e⁢tsubscript𝑆𝑡𝑎𝑟𝑔𝑒𝑡S_{target}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_a italic_r italic_g italic_e italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which is then added to M𝑀Mitalic_M (Lines 11-14). Take the example shown in Fig. 4 again. We first collect the words in the translation that are not aligned with any input words as Tu⁢n⁢a⁢l⁢i⁢g⁢n⁢e⁢dsubscript𝑇𝑢𝑛𝑎𝑙𝑖𝑔𝑛𝑒𝑑T_{unaligned}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u italic_n italic_a italic_l italic_i italic_g italic_n italic_e italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT:{“月份”, “都”, “大”}. We then utilize the Stanford parser to obtain the constituency parse tree of the translation, as shown on the right of Fig. 4. Then, for the first word “月份” in Tu⁢n⁢a⁢l⁢i⁢g⁢n⁢e⁢dsubscript𝑇𝑢𝑛𝑎𝑙𝑖𝑔𝑛𝑒𝑑T_{unaligned}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u italic_n italic_a italic_l italic_i italic_g italic_n italic_e italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we locate the smallest subtree marked as a noun phrase comprising the words of “1” and “月份”, as indicated by the dashed box. According to the basic word alignments, “1” is aligned with “January” but “月份” is aligned with nothing. Thus, as indicated by the blue arrow, we build the missed alignment between “January” and “月份”. With similar steps, we also build the missed alignment between “pandemic” and “大”. Finally, following refinement strategy 1, the “January” and “pandemic” are correctly aligned with their translations “1” and “月份”, and “大” and “流行”.

Refinement strategy 2: Our refinement strategy 2 is based on the idea that each unique output word that appears in both Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT should be aligned with the same input word. The same input word is generally translated as the same output words in Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Therefore, the unique output words shared by Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT should correspond with the same input word. However, the word alignment tool may miss the alignments between the input word and its identical translation in Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT or Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. As shown in Fig. 5, due to the missed word alignment made by AWESOME, the unique output words “更” and “容易” in Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are aligned with different input words. Specifically, the word “更” in Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is aligned with “easier” but the word “更” in Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is aligned with nothing. Similarly, the word “容易” in Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is aligned with “easier” but the word “容易” in Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is aligned with nothing. Both missed word alignments can not be built by refinement strategy 1 because “更” and “容易” are included in a verb phrase in both Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Refinement strategy 2 aims to build the missed alignments of the unique and same output words by comparing the alignments between Sssubscript𝑆𝑠S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and between Sfsubscript𝑆𝑓S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Algorithm 2 illustrates the steps of the refinement strategy 2. We first identify all the same and unique words between Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as Tu⁢n⁢i⁢q⁢u⁢esubscript𝑇𝑢𝑛𝑖𝑞𝑢𝑒T_{unique}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u italic_n italic_i italic_q italic_u italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (Line 1). Next, for each word wtsubscript𝑤𝑡w_{t}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in Tu⁢n⁢i⁢q⁢u⁢esubscript𝑇𝑢𝑛𝑖𝑞𝑢𝑒T_{unique}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u italic_n italic_i italic_q italic_u italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we compare whether its aligned input words in Sssubscript𝑆𝑠S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Sfsubscript𝑆𝑓S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are different(Lines 2-3). If its aligned words in Sssubscript𝑆𝑠S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Sfsubscript𝑆𝑓S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are different, we get the union of them as St⁢a⁢r⁢g⁢e⁢tsubscript𝑆𝑡𝑎𝑟𝑔𝑒𝑡S_{target}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_a italic_r italic_g italic_e italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (Line 4). As mentioned above, i.e., the word wtsubscript𝑤𝑡w_{t}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is supposed to align with the same input words in Sssubscript𝑆𝑠S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Sfsubscript𝑆𝑓S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we iterate through each word wssubscript𝑤𝑠w_{s}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in St⁢a⁢r⁢g⁢e⁢tsubscript𝑆𝑡𝑎𝑟𝑔𝑒𝑡S_{target}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_a italic_r italic_g italic_e italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to establish the missed alignment between wssubscript𝑤𝑠w_{s}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in Sssubscript𝑆𝑠S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (Sfsubscript𝑆𝑓S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) and wtsubscript𝑤𝑡w_{t}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT), which is then added to Mssubscript𝑀𝑠M_{s}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (Mfsubscript𝑀𝑓M_{f}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) (Lines 5-9). For instance presented in Fig. 5, we initially collect the same and unique words between Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as Tu⁢n⁢i⁢q⁢u⁢esubscript𝑇𝑢𝑛𝑖𝑞𝑢𝑒T_{unique}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u italic_n italic_i italic_q italic_u italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT:{“小”, “芝麻”, “更”, “容易”, “在”, “市场”, “上”, “销售”}. Then, we traverse each word in Tu⁢n⁢i⁢q⁢u⁢esubscript𝑇𝑢𝑛𝑖𝑞𝑢𝑒T_{unique}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u italic_n italic_i italic_q italic_u italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to compare its aligned words in Sssubscript𝑆𝑠S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Sfsubscript𝑆𝑓S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We find that “更” is aligned with {“easier”} in Sssubscript𝑆𝑠S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT but is not aligned with any words in Sfsubscript𝑆𝑓S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Therefore, as marked by the blue arrow, we build the missed alignment between “easier” in Sfsubscript𝑆𝑓S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and “更” in Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. With similar steps, we also build the missed alignment between “容易” in Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and “easier” in Sssubscript𝑆𝑠S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Ultimately, “easier” is correctly aligned with its translations “更” and “容易” in both source and follow-up translations.

4.4. Word Closure Construction

This module constructs all word closures ℂ={𝒞1,𝒞2,…,𝒞k}ℂsubscript𝒞1subscript𝒞2…subscript𝒞𝑘\mathbb{C}{=}\{\mathcal{C}_{1},\mathcal{C}_{2},\dots,\mathcal{C}_{k}\}blackboard_C = { caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } for a metamorphic test case pair. The construction process is illustrated in Algorithm 3. This process begins with adding one input word from either Sssubscript𝑆𝑠S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT or Sfsubscript𝑆𝑓S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to act as the initial word of a new closure. Subsequently, we continually iterate through each word within the closure to add its correlated words within the test cases into the closure until no further new words can be added. At the very beginning, all words in Sssubscript𝑆𝑠S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Sfsubscript𝑆𝑓S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are labeled as UNMARKED, which indicates they are not associated with no word closure (Lines 14-15).

We denote the four sets (defined in Definition 4.1) in one single word closure 𝒞isubscript𝒞𝑖\mathcal{C}_{i}caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as Cs⁢e⁢n⁢tssuperscriptsubscript𝐶𝑠𝑒𝑛𝑡𝑠C_{sent}^{s}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_e italic_n italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, Ct⁢r⁢a⁢nssuperscriptsubscript𝐶𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑛𝑠C_{tran}^{s}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_r italic_a italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, Cs⁢e⁢n⁢tfsuperscriptsubscript𝐶𝑠𝑒𝑛𝑡𝑓C_{sent}^{f}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_e italic_n italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and Ct⁢r⁢a⁢nfsuperscriptsubscript𝐶𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑛𝑓C_{tran}^{f}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_r italic_a italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, respectively. Initially, these four sets are empty (Line 19). The whole construction starts from the first input word in Sssubscript𝑆𝑠S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (Line 17). This word is added into Cs⁢e⁢n⁢tssuperscriptsubscript𝐶𝑠𝑒𝑛𝑡𝑠C_{sent}^{s}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_e italic_n italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of the very first word closure 𝒞1subscript𝒞1\mathcal{C}_{1}caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (Line 20). Then, we begin to update the four sets by looping through the following six steps within the closure function until no further changes to the four sets (Line 22):
